isis.stitle: DT-466E and 530E Diesel Engine Diagnostics Model Years 1999-2000 - ELECTRONIC CONTROL SYSTEM DIAGNOSTICS - Circuit Function And Diagnostics - Remote PTO Speed Control (RPTO)

svcsubproc.title: System Function

figure.caption: Function Diagram for Remote PTO Speed Control

svcsubproc.para: The remote power take off allows control of engine speed by remote switches for auxillary engine devices such as hydraulic pumps and lift gates.

Variable speed or preset PTO control (up to two preset speeds) can be selected and programmed in the ECM with the Electronic Service Tool (EST). The mode (variable or preset PTO) must be selected and turned on by the EST tool for this feature to function. On/off switches must also be installed to provide a 12V signal to the appropriate pin in the ECM. The Remote PTO feature will be disabled when vehicle speed is detected, the clutch pedal is depressed or if the transmission is put into gear (automatic transmission only).

Variable PTO speed is either increased or decreased by depressing the momentary speed control switch to the Set or Resume position. The speed at which the engine accelerates is noted as the ramp rate or rpm per seconds of acceleration that the engine is allowed to accelerate. Ramp rate and maximum PTO speed are programmable by using the Electronic Service Tool (EST).

In the preset PTO mode, the momentary speed control switch allows selection of two preset speeds. By momentarily depressing the switch in preset mode 1, the first speed is selected; by momentarily depressing the switch in preset position 2, a second speed can be selected. Both speeds are programmable in the ECM by using the Electronic Service Tool (EST).

svcsubproc.title: Fault Detection / Management
svcsubproc.para: If disagreements in speed selection states are detected by the ECM a Diagnostic Trouble Code will be set. The most common source of RPTO problems are blown fuses to the on/off circuit, an incorrectly programmed ECM, or wiring the body builder connectors and speed control switches improperly.

svcsubproc.title: Extended Description
svcsubproc.para: Power Take Off (PTO) speed control allows the operator to set and maintain a regulated engine speed, without using the accelerator pedal to operate auxiliary equipment. The power take off has an in-cab and a remote operator interface. Depending on configuration, the operator can activate PTO speed control while in the cab or by remote interface. If both in-cab and remote operations are enabled, the on-board electronics senses which interface is active depending on operator actions. No active mobile PTO operation is possible when the PTO speed control is turned on using the remote interface.

This feature also has the bump up and bump down functions. Wherein, the operator may bump up the rpm in 25 rpm increments when the Resume/Accel button is momentarily pressed. The operator may bump down the rpm in 25 rpm increments when the Set/Coast button is momentarily pressed.
This parameter indicates to the on-board electronics if the vehicle has the Power Take Off speed control feature.

item.para: Disable: Feature is turned off at all times.
Remote Operation Only: Feature is enabled and may only be turned on and activated using the remote PTO ON/OFF switches.
In-Cab Operation Only: Feature is enabled and uses PTO in-cab Mode as the discriminate factor as to how the on-board electronics will apply PTO speed control while in the in-cab operation.
Remote and In-Cab Operation: Feature is enabled and allows remote and in-cab operations. However, the remote operation takes precedence over the in-cab operations.

svcsubproc.para: This parameter indicates the maximum road speed that the PTO speed control may be engaged while in Mobile PTO operation.
This parameter indicates how the dashboard mounted Cruise Control switches are to be interpreted.

item.para: None: The dashboard mounted Cruise Control ON/OFF switch is ignored.
Stationary Preset: The dashboard mounted Cruise Control switches are to operate only in the Preset state of operation.
Stationary Variable: The dashboard mounted Cruise Control switches are to operate in a variable state of operation.
Mobile Variable: The dashboard mounted Cruise Control switches are to operate in a variable state of operation while allowing the vehicle to be mobile.

svcsubproc.para: This parameter indicates to the on-board electronics if PTO speed control is on and active. If active, the operator in-cab interfaces are ignored. These interfaces include accelerator pedal, driveline engagement signal, brake pedal and the dashboard mounted Cruise Control switches.

item.para: Enable: Continue to monitor in-cab operator interfaces.

svcsubproc.para: This parameter indicates to the on-board electronics if a remote throttle control is available for use to control the PTO rpm setting.

item.para: Disable: Remote throttle is not available.

svcsubproc.para: This parameter indicates the rpm setting when the operator depresses the Set/Coast button with the STATIONARY PRESET in-cab mode of operation.
This parameter indicates the rpm setting when the operator depresses the Resume/Accel button with the Stationary Preset in-cab mode of operation.
This parameter indicates the rate at which the rpm is to be increased when the operator depresses and holds the Resume/Accel button.
This parameter indicates the maximum rpm that the PTO speed control may be engaged.

para.emph: Cruise PTO Control Switch Circuit Diagnostic Trouble Code

svcsubproc.para: The ECM monitors the cruise control switches and PTO inputs (both in-cab and remote). If the expected values for each input do not match the expected status, a Diagnostic Trouble Code is set.

The EST can be used to monitor the status of the PTO controls. Comparing the data list reading to actual operation will indicate if the controls are operating properly. Using the menu of programmable parameters, the ECM programming can also be verified to insure that the ECM is properly programmed for PTO applications.
